answers.feedback_html: Light may or may not be polarized, but that does not affect its wavefront formation, which determines its nonparallel behavior.
Light is reflected, but that is not the reason that the beam spreads out.
Monochromatic light does not spread out due to refraction.
The beam of light spreads out because of diffraction of its wavefronts.

stem_html: A beam of light always spreads out. Why can a beam not be produced with parallel rays to prevent spreading?

answers.content_html: No, it is not a natural science because it is not used in the study of the natural world.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics is used in the study of the natural world, but that does not explain whether it is a natural science.

answers.content_html: No, it is not a natural science. Mathematics focuses on understanding mathematical relations and calculations, which is useful in natural sciences but which is distinct.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics is not a natural science as it does not use chemical and physical measurements like other fields in natural sciences.

answers.content_html: Yes, it is a natural science. Mathematics deals with verifying the experimental data.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics does not use the chemical and physical measurements, therefore it is not natural science.

answers.content_html: Yes, it is a natural science. It uses chemical and physical measurements.
answers.feedback_html: Mathematics does not use chemical and physical measurements.

stem_html: Is mathematics a natural science? Explain your reasoning.

answers.feedback_html: If the color trait is completely dominant, the F1 generation would have been all red or all blue depending on the dominant allele, but here we obtained violet color flowers.
In codominance, both alleles of a gene express equally.

A cross between a blue (BB) flower and a red (RR) flower produces all violet (BR) flowers as a result of incomplete dominance. Both alleles when present produce intermediate inheritance, in which one allele for the trait is not completely expressed over its paired allele.
Try to recall the deviations from Mendelian inheritance.

stem_html: Petunias can be blue, red, or violet. When a blue flower is crossed with a red flower, all the resulting flowers are violet. When a violet flower is crossed with a red flower, about half of the flowers are violet and half are red. How do you characterize the color trait?
